page.title: 08LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Elsfield was probably established as a community since Anglo Saxon times. John Buchan, Lord Tweedsmuir, a Governor General of Canada and a prolific author, lived in the Manor House. His novel "Midwinter" opens with a scene on nearby Otmoor. Francis Wise, the antiquary, lived at the Manor House when he was librarian at the Bodleian (1748_67) and was visited there by Dr Johnson. In recent times a Professor of Japanese at Oxford University lived in Woodeaton and is buried in the churchyard. Lower Woods farm is part Tudor, and in the yard are two enormous oak trees which supposedly date back to the 16th century. Elsfield is derived from the Anglo_Saxon meaning "The field of Ella or Elesa". Woodeaton means "The wood by the meadows".
